<target_code>
Here is the code of atomic:
```c
static int atomic(void)
{
	const int threads = 10;
	atomic_int counter = ATOMIC_VAR_INIT(0);
	int value, error;

	error = metal_run(threads, atomic_thread, &counter);
	if (!error) {
		value = atomic_load(&counter);
		value -= atomic_test_count * threads;
		if (value) {
			metal_log(METAL_LOG_DEBUG, "counter mismatch, delta = %d\n",
				  value);
			error = -EINVAL;
		}
	}

	return error;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function atomic:
static void *atomic_thread(void *arg)
{
	atomic_int *c = arg;
	int i;

	for (i = 0; i < atomic_test_count; i++)
		atomic_fetch_add(c, 1);

	return NULL;
}
...
int metal_run(int threads, metal_thread_t child, void *arg)
{
	pthread_t tids[threads];
	int error, ts_created;

	error = metal_run_noblock(threads, child, arg, tids, &ts_created);

	metal_finish_threads(ts_created, (void *)tids);

	return error;
}
...
static const int atomic_test_count = 1000
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags: int metal_run(int threads, metal_thread_t child, void *arg)
explanation: Fragments not listed do not need investigation for Rule 8.13 because they either (a) modify the pointed-to object (so a non-const pointer is required) or (b) do not involve pointer-to-object types that could be const-qualified. Specifically: - atomic_thread(void *arg) and the assignment atomic_int *c = arg: the thread body calls atomic_fetch_add to modify *c, so the pointee must be non-const. - The local atomic_int counter is written by threads, so passing its address requires a non-const pointer. - atomic_load/atomic_fetch_add usages operate on a mutable atomic_int, so const qualification is not appropriate. - The declaration of pthread_t tids[threads] is an array of thread IDs (not a candidate for making the array element type const here). Therefore only the listed function parameter/forwarding sites and the explicit cast to (void *) warrant further inspection to determine whether their pointer parameters could or should be const-qualified.
